title: Regional States in Medieval Islamic Geography

text: With the weakening of the influence of the Abbasids, new political structures emerged in different regions of the Islamic world. Independently of their ethnic or geographical identities, these states undertook important duties such as ensuring order in their own regions, developing scientific and cultural activities, and keeping trade alive. Therefore, this period is evaluated as a process where more than one power existed together in a wide geography rather than a single-centered structure.

Although the Seljuks were a community coming from Central Asia, they became a strong political balance element in the Islamic world in a short time. Their administration aimed to protect the Abbasid caliph from external threats and strengthen the central authority.

The Seljuks institutionalized the madrasa system under the leadership of Nizam al-Mulk. These institutions were not only educational centers; they were also structures contributing to the development of social order and intellectual life.

content.section: b) Geographic Power and Political Influence
text: Controlling a wide geography helped maintain stability in the Islamic world for a long time. The Seljuks succeeded in keeping different communities together under the same administrative roof.
The Ghaznavids were active in the northern regions of Khorasan and India. This state drew attention not only with its military power but also with its support for scientific activities in the region.

content.section: a) Environment of Science and Culture
text: Ghaznavid palaces became a center for scholars, poets, and historians. This environment played a major role in the development of Persian literature.
The Ghaznavids maintained the economic vitality of the region by protecting trade routes. The order they established in the geography of India increased cultural interaction.
The Fatimids were a North Africa-based state and then settled in Egypt, transforming Cairo into a strong center of culture and administration.

Cairo became one of the important cultural centers of the period with its mosques, libraries, and educational institutions. The al-Azhar institution established in this period became an important element of the Islamic education tradition.
The Fatimids ensured economic stability in the region by organizing Mediterranean trade routes. This situation increased Egypt's welfare level.

The Buyids became an effective regional power around Baghdad where the Abbasid caliph continued. Without touching the religious authority of the Caliph, they directed the administrative and military structure.
In this period, production in literature, philosophy, and medicine intensified in Baghdad. Scientists were supported in palace and city centers.
The Buyids tried to maintain a polyphonic structure by including different ethnic and cultural elements in the administration.

The Mamluks established a strong state structure, especially in the Egypt and Syria region. In a period when the Mongol invasion spread rapidly, they defended the important centers of the Islamic world by protecting the region.

The Mamluks prevented the destruction of the western regions of the Islamic world with the critical struggles they won against the Mongols. This success significantly affected the political balances of the period.

Cairo experienced one of its brightest periods in terms of art and architecture during the Mamluk period. Madrasas, mosques, and caravanserais are the characteristic architectural structures of this period.

The common feature of these states that emerged in the Medieval Islamic geography is their efforts to ensure order in their regions, keep economic life alive, and support scientific-cultural activities. These states:
-Despite having different identities,
-Within the same civilization area,
-Provided strong contributions in production, education, defense, and urbanization.
Therefore, the period in question is evaluated as a phase where Islamic civilization matured within regional diversity.
